Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: This morning, I stood at the foot of Mr. Harris’s bed, gently coaxing him to sit up. His surgery had left him weak, and every movement was a careful negotiation between pain and necessity. As a nursing assistant, I knew my duty was to help him dress, to make sure he felt safe and cared for. But my mind kept drifting to the convent’s kitchen, where my sisters were already bustling about, preparing for the monthly food drive. As a nun, I was expected to be there, hands deep in flour, heart open to the needs of the hungry. The clock ticked louder with every passing minute, and I felt the weight of both uniforms pressing on my shoulders. Mr. Harris looked at me, trusting, vulnerable. I could almost hear Sister Agnes’s gentle reminder: “Charity begins at home, but it must not end there.” My heart ached, torn between the patient before me and the community waiting beyond these hospital walls.
